terms.definition: Document from your employer reporting wages and taxes withheld. Provided by January 31 each year; shows your earnings and what was already paid to IRS.
terms.example: Key boxes: Box 1 (wages), Box 2 (federal tax withheld)

terms.definition: Documents reporting income from sources other than employment‚Äîfreelance work, investments, bank interest. No taxes are automatically withheld.
The main federal income tax return form for individuals. Report all income, claim deductions and credits, calculate what you owe (or are owed).
terms.example: May include schedules: A (itemized), C (self-employment), D (capital gains)

terms.definition: Minimum income level at which you're required to file a tax return. Based on age, filing status, and income type‚Äîadjusted annually for inflation.
terms.example: 2024: Single under 65 = $14,600; Self-employed $400+ always must file

highlightBox.text: Self-employment income of $400 or more always requires filing‚Äîregardless of other thresholds!

leftPanel.title: 5 Filing Statuses
bulletPoints: Single: Unmarried, divorced, or legally separated
Married Filing Jointly: Combined income, one return
Married Filing Separately: Separate returns
Head of Household: Unmarried, support dependents
Qualifying Widow(er): Spouse died in past 2 years

highlightBox.text: Your status affects tax rates, standard deduction, and credit eligibility!

content.headerTitle: Why File Even If Not Required?

leftPanel.title: Don't Leave Money on the Table!
bulletPoints: Get withheld taxes back: If employer withheld taxes but you owe nothing, only filing gets it back
Claim refundable credits: Earned Income Tax Credit can give a refund even if you owe $0
Prevent identity theft: File first so no one can fraudulently use your SSN
Build your record: Tax returns verify income for loans, FAFSA, apartments

stats.label: Potential refund you might be missing
Simple returns often take to file

layoutData.title: Tax Filing = Financial Foundation
paragraphs: Understanding tax filing is an essential life skill with far-reaching implications.
bulletPoints: Financial Planning: Budget for taxes, avoid surprises
Career Decisions: W-2 vs. 1099 has different tax impacts
Legal Compliance: Avoid penalties and potential criminal charges
Financial Aid: FAFSA requires tax return information
Major Purchases: Mortgages and loans require tax return history

keyPoint.text: üí° Tax filing is typically the first major government financial interaction for most adults‚Äîyour tax history follows you forever.

leftPanel.title: Freelance? Side Hustle? Gig Work?
bulletPoints: $400+ = must file regardless of other income thresholds
Self-employment tax: ~15.3% for Social Security + Medicare
No withholding: You must save and pay taxes yourself
Quarterly payments: May need to pay estimated taxes 4x/year
Schedule C: Report income and deduct business expenses

stats.label: Recommended to set aside from 1099 income

scenario.name: Ava: Filing for a Refund ‚Äî High School Student with Part-Time Job
paragraphs: Ava earned $4,500 last year‚Äîwell below the $14,600 filing threshold. Her employer withheld $380 in federal taxes from her paychecks throughout the year.

Even though she's NOT required to file, she SHOULD file. At her income level, she owes $0 in taxes‚Äîfiling gets all $380 back! If she doesn't file within 3 years, that money becomes property of the U.S. Treasury.

scenario.name: Ben: Multiple Income Sources ‚Äî Full-Time + Freelance
paragraphs: Ben earned $32,000 from his retail job (W-2) plus $5,000 from freelance graphic design (1099-NEC). He must file for two reasons: total income exceeds threshold AND self-employment income exceeds $400.

Ben needs Form 1040, Schedule C (business income/expenses), and Schedule SE (self-employment tax). He'll owe ~$765 in self-employment tax on his freelance income, but can deduct business expenses like software and equipment.

takeaways.description: Filing requirements depend on income, age, and status‚Äîbut self-employment income of $400+ always requires filing

main.title: Find and Analyze Tax Forms
main.description: Search for sample W-2, 1099-NEC, and Form 1040 forms online. Take screenshots and identify key information fields on each form. Resources: IRS.gov has sample forms‚Äîsearch 'IRS W-2 sample' or 'IRS Form 1040.'

steps: Find an example of each form online (W-2, 1099-NEC, Form 1040)
Take a screenshot focusing on key fields
Write a one-sentence explanation of the form's purpose
Identify 3-5 key fields and what information they contain
Apply to a scenario: Which forms would Ava, Ben, or another student need?
